misconceptions.name: Implemented a different program instead of the specified number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a 'RoadTripCost' program that calculates the cost of driving based on distance, MPG, and gas price, instead of implementing the required number guessing game with a random number between 1 and 100, repeated guesses, and high/low hints.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that submitting any working Java program (in this case, a road trip cost calculator) is acceptable for this question, or they may have confused this problem with a different assignment about trip cost.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must implement a number guessing game: generate a random integer between 1 and 100 using Random, repeatedly prompt the user to guess until they get the number correct, and after each incorrect guess print whether it was 'Too high' or 'Too low'. The program should count and report how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Class is named RoadTripCost, not something related to guessing or games.
Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of asking for a guess between 1 and 100.
No Random object is created; no random number is generated.
No loop is present to allow multiple guesses.
No conditional logic to print 'Too high' or 'Too low'.
Program performs a single arithmetic calculation and prints a cost, then exits.
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely the student reused or pasted code from a different exercise (road trip cost calculation) or misread which problem they were solving, leading them to implement an entirely different specification instead of the number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start from scratch for this question. Implement the required number guessing game: (1) create a Random object and generate an int answer between 1 and 100, (2) use a loop (while or do-while) to repeatedly ask the user 'Guess a number (1-100):', (3) compare each guess to answer and print 'Too high!' or 'Too low!' when incorrect, and (4) stop the loop when the guess is correct and print the total number of guesses.
related_concepts: Random number generation in Java (Random and nextInt)
Program design for interactive console games
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because every part of the submitted code (class name, prompts, variables, and formula) corresponds to a road trip cost calculator and none of the required elements of a number guessing game (random number, guesses, hints, loop) are present.

evidence.note: This entire file implements a road trip cost calculator and contains no random number generation, guessing loop, or high/low feedback required for the number guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Assignment Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for the 'Road Trip Cost Calculation' problem instead of the requested 'Number Guessing Game' (Q2). The entire implementation is incorrect for the specified task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the provided `RoadTripCost.java` file fulfills the requirements of Q2: Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student was required to implement a program featuring random number generation, input loops, and conditional feedback ('Too high', 'Too low').
symptoms: Code prompts for distance, MPG, and fuel price.
Code calculates fuel cost.
Absence of loop structures (while/do-while).
Absence of conditional logic to compare a guess against a secret number.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misplaced or incorrect file submission, or fundamental misunderstanding of which assignment was due for Q2.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment instructions and submit the correctly implemented code for the Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code's purpose (calculating fuel cost) is entirely distinct from the assignment's purpose (implementing a guessing game).

evidence.note: The class and file names are related to an entirely different problem (Road Trip Cost).
The input prompts confirm the program solves a fuel cost calculation problem, not the required number guessing game.
The core logic is mathematical calculation, not game control flow (loops, conditionals for feedback).

misconceptions.name: Wrong assignment submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted a complete solution to a different problem (Road Trip Cost Calculator) instead of the required Number Guessing Game. This indicates either a file mix-up, fundamental misreading of requirements, or submission error.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were solving the Road Trip Cost problem, or made a file selection error.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q2 requires implementing a Number Guessing Game where the computer picks a random number 1-100, the user guesses repeatedly, and receives 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback until the correct guess is made.
symptoms: Submitted code solves an entirely different problem
No Random number generation present
No guessing loop implemented
No high/low comparison logic
No game termination condition
All 5 rubric points cannot be awarded
misconceptions.root_cause: Critical submission error—either wrong file submitted, misread assignment requirements, or file mix-up between multiple assignments.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read Q2 requirements. Implement a new solution with: (1) Random number 1-100, (2) while loop for guesses, (3) comparison logic with 'Too high'/'Too low' output, (4) guess counter, (5) termination when correct.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty—the submitted code is for Road Trip Cost, which is objectively not the Number Guessing Game. No ambiguity possible.

evidence.note: Entire submission solves Road Trip Cost problem. No Random import, no guessing loop, no 'Too high'/'Too low' logic, no game structure.
Missing 'import java.util.Random;' which is required for the guessing game and explicitly mentioned in the problem hint.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different program instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a road trip cost calculator rather than the specified number guessing game. The program has no random number generation, no guessing loop, and no feedback of "Too high" or "Too low".
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon, then computes and prints the cost of driving.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must be a number guessing game: generate a random integer between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess until they are correct, and after each incorrect guess print whether it was too high or too low, finally reporting how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Class and program name refer to road trip cost, not a guessing game
No use of Random or random number generation
No loop structure for repeated guessing
No conditional logic comparing a guess to a secret number
Program only performs arithmetic on distance, mpg, and pricePerGallon
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignments or copying the wrong template/file, leading to implementing an unrelated specification instead of the required number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard or move this road trip cost code to the appropriate question/file, then re-implement Q2 according to the number guessing game specification: use Random to pick a number between 1 and 100, use a loop to keep asking for guesses until correct, and compare each guess to the secret number to print "Too high" or "Too low".
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire class is devoted to computing driving cost with distance/mpg/price input and contains no elements of a number guessing game, making it almost certain the student implemented the wrong program.

evidence.note: Code computes road trip cost using distance, mpg, and price instead of implementing any part of a number guessing game; there is no Random, no guessing loop, and no high/low feedback.
